results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.
results.question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?

Helpful Answer:
Anyone born in or who has lived continuously (without interruption) within an EU/EEA country since birth can acquire Irish nationality by descent.
If you were adopted as such from one parent at least 5 years prior but not more than 21 on July 30th last year then this would also qualify under "Birth Without Parental Consent" provision if there was no parental objection during that period
The only exception being those with dual national status where they have acquired their second passport through marriage abroad; however these individuals will retain both passports upon application

Please note I am aware it may be considered sensitive territory so please do keep things civil when responding! My aim here though remains providing accurate guidance based on current law applicable throughout all aspects of my
results.answer:
Anyone born in or who has lived continuously (without interruption) within an EU/EEA country since birth can acquire Irish nationality by descent.
If you were adopted as such from one parent at least 5 years prior but not more than 21 on July 30th last year then this would also qualify under "Birth Without Parental Consent" provision if there was no parental objection during that period
The only exception being those with dual national status where they have acquired their second passport through marriage abroad; however these individuals will retain both passports upon application

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.
results.question: What is ordinary residence?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is ordinary residence?

Helpful Answer:
Ordinary Residence refers to where an individual lives in preference over another location within their country or internationally.
In practical terms this means that when you move abroad it may be necessary to register with local authorities as they have different rules about what documents can apply depending on whether someone has "ordinary" residency status versus not having such rights.
This article will provide some background on how Ordinary Residency works across Europe (and other countries) - so if there’s anything specific related to Ireland I'd like help finding out more! Let me know which topic(s), please?

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:
Genuine redundancies in Ireland must meet certain criteria set by law:

1) The company needs restructuring or closure.
2) It cannot afford its employees anymore due to financial difficulties (e.g., bankruptcy).
3) Employees have been given notice according to their contract terms ("giving 4 weeks' written warning").
  
If these conditions apply then any job losses that result from them qualify under national legislation on "Redundancy Payments". These payments include both unemployment benefits AND statutory compensation known as Statutory Redundant Pay which is paid out at an average rate based upon earnings over last year before leaving work - it varies depending where you live within country but can be up-to €60 per hour plus other allowances like housing allowance etc... 

In
results.answer:
Genuine redundancies in Ireland must meet certain criteria set by law:

1) The company needs restructuring or closure.
2) It cannot afford its employees anymore due to financial difficulties (e.g., bankruptcy).
3) Employees have been given notice according to their contract terms ("giving 4 weeks' written warning").
  
If these conditions apply then any job losses that result from them qualify under national legislation on "Redundancy Payments". These payments include both unemployment benefits AND statutory compensation known as Statutory Redundant Pay which is paid out at an average rate based upon earnings over last year before leaving work - it varies depending where you live within country but can be up-to €60 per hour plus other allowances like housing allowance etc...

results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A "GP Visit Card" in Ireland refers specifically to an appointment booking system used by General Practitioners (GPs) when they need additional time with their patients due to unforeseen circumstances or if there has been some delay on their end.
It was introduced as part of measures taken after 2013 where GPs had difficulty finding enough appointments at short notice because many were booked out months before but still needed more time during busy periods like Christmas week - this made it difficult for both doctors' schedules being filled up too quickly while also making patient waiting times longer than expected especially around major events such as weddings etc...
The cards allow people who have missed any reason from attending planned medical check-ups/visits without having to call ahead every single
results.answer:
A "GP Visit Card" in Ireland refers specifically to an appointment booking system used by General Practitioners (GPs) when they need additional time with their patients due to unforeseen circumstances or if there has been some delay on their end.
It was introduced as part of measures taken after 2013 where GPs had difficulty finding enough appointments at short notice because many were booked out months before but still needed more time during busy periods like Christmas week - this made it difficult for both doctors' schedules being filled up too quickly while also making patient waiting times longer than expected especially around major events such as weddings etc...

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.
results.question: Who can get a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:

Question: Who can get a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A general practitioner (GP) is someone who has been trained in medicine or surgery so that they know how to diagnose illnesses such as colds.
To book an appointment with one you need either a medical certificate from another doctor stating why it would be safe for them not to go out at this time,
or if there isn't anyone else available on their usual opening days then we will try our best to find some other options within 24 hours after receiving
the request through email/phone/text message etc.. If no appointments have become free by day two than I'm afraid we'll just let people wait until next month! 😢😢

The above text explains what makes up a G.P., but also provides details about booking visits when needed due

or if there isn't anyone else available on their usual opening days then we will try our best to find some other options within 24 hours after receiving

results.ground_truth: Online applications are completed in approximately 20 working days for first-time applicants. If you are applying by post, you should allow at least 8 weeks for your application to be processed (not including postage times). This period may be extended at certain times of the year due to increased application numbers. First-time postal applications from the UK take at least 8 weeks. You can check the Passport Service website for current processing times.

2) For forms submitted by post – which can be returned if they're not complete within two months after posting date,
    You'll need approximately four-to-six-weeks depending upon when we receive them back with all necessary documents completed correctly,

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:
A police certificate in Ireland refers to an identity document issued by local or national authorities that verifies someone’s personal details such as name, address, date of birth etc., but it doesn't include fingerprints like some other countries' similar documents might have.
In simple terms:

- It can be used when you're applying online with certain government services
- For example, if you need proof of ID while traveling abroad 
- Or maybe just want one on file

Remember though - this isn’t something everyone needs; many people don’t carry them around all day long! 

So whether you've got yours handy (or not) depends more than anything else how important those particular situations may feel!

If there was ever any confusion about what "police" means

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.
results.question: How to register to vote?
results.raw_answer:

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:
To become eligible in order to participate as an elector or voter when you're registered with Citizens' Advice Bureau (CAB), here’s what we recommend:

1) You must be 20 years old on polling day
- If not yet reached this age at election time then wait until next general poll

2) Be domiciled within one local electoral area 
   - Local authority district is usually given by street name e.g., Dublin city centre will have its own separate electorate 

3) Have lived there continuously since birth/arrival if under 56 yrs-old  
    Or last been resident legally before turning 48 yr-olds  

Please note that these rules may vary slightly based upon specific circumstances such as residency status abroad during certain periods

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.
results.question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Helpful Answer:
The vacant property refurbishment grant in Ireland provides financial support towards improving or converting an empty house into suitable living accommodation.
This assistance covers up-front costs such as building works (such as installing heating systems), structural alterations needed before letting out the space again after renovation work has been completed; also includes materials like paint that can be used during renovations but not purchased separately from other items on their own - it’s aimed at helping people who want to convert old houses back into homes rather than sell them off completely unused due to lack of funds available through traditional routes...
It was announced by Minister Simon Harris' Department of Housing Communities & Local Government with its first round being released between 2019-3 onwards! The application process involves filling forms online which need

The vacant property refurbishment grant in Ireland provides financial support towards improving or converting an empty house into suitable living accommodation.
This assistance covers up-front costs such as building works (such as installing heating systems), structural alterations needed before letting out the space again after renovation work has been completed; also includes materials like paint that can be used during renovations but not purchased separately from other items on their own - it’s aimed at helping people who want to convert old houses back into homes rather than sell them off completely unused due to lack of funds available through traditional routes...
It was announced by Minister Simon Harris' Department of Housing Communities & Local Government with its first round being released between 2019-3 onwards!

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
No, employers cannot legally compel you to work during any period that is designated as an employee’s entitlements under national law or collective agreement (e.g., statutory holidays). If employees choose not to go on holiday they should be entitled by contract terms agreed with their company.
In fact there have been cases where companies were forced into paying out money when it was found this had happened due to non-compliance in taking time off - see here:

https://www.hse.ie/eng/news/pr1026.html

If anyone has more detailed questions about employment rights I can help answer those too but please remember these answers relate only specifically to legal matters within state agencies like myself which may differ from private sector agreements between businesses & individuals if applicable
I
results.answer:
No, employers cannot legally compel you to work during any period that is designated as an employee’s entitlements under national law or collective agreement (e.g., statutory holidays). If employees choose not to go on holiday they should be entitled by contract terms agreed with their company.
In fact there have been cases where companies were forced into paying out money when it was found this had happened due to non-compliance in taking time off - see here:

https://www.hse.ie/eng/news/pr1026.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.
results.question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
If you become ill during an Annual Leave period in Ireland, it is important that you follow these steps:

1) First thing first - please contact us at Citizens' Advice Bureau (CAB), which offers free confidential advice from qualified professionals who can provide guidance tailored specifically towards those experiencing personal difficulties or crises.
2) CAB will be able to offer immediate support by providing emergency services like medical assistance as well as emotional counseling over phone lines 0895-7364/0875-7364

Please do not hesitate contacting them immediately so they may assist with any necessary actions required based upon their expertise regarding such situations occurring within this context where there might otherwise exist potential legal consequences arising out thereof should one failfully neglect
results.answer:
If you become ill during an Annual Leave period in Ireland, it is important that you follow these steps:

1) First thing first - please contact us at Citizens' Advice Bureau (CAB), which offers free confidential advice from qualified professionals who can provide guidance tailored specifically towards those experiencing personal difficulties or crises.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially
results.question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

Helpful Answer:
A tenant in Northern Ireland can end their rental agreement by giving notice as soon as they move into accommodation under an assured shorthold tenancy (AST). This means that tenants have no right or obligation not earlier than six weeks before moving out.
In order to give proper notice within this time frame it must be given "in writing" - i.e., on paper with all necessary details included such as who you're notifying about what action being taken etcetera. If someone gives oral warning instead then there may still exist some formality which needs filling up later but generally speaking if something has been said over phone/email/letter/etc then at least one copy should get sent along too so things aren't forgotten!
If anyone wants more specific guidance around when
results.answer:
A tenant in Northern Ireland can end their rental agreement by giving notice as soon as they move into accommodation under an assured shorthold tenancy (AST). This means that tenants have no right or obligation not earlier than six weeks before moving out.
In order to give proper notice within this time frame it must be given "in writing" - i.e., on paper with all necessary details included such as who you're notifying about what action being taken etcetera. If someone gives oral warning instead then there may still exist some formality which needs filling up later but generally speaking if something has been said over phone/email/letter/etc then at least one copy should get sent along too so things aren't forgotten!

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.
results.question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:
When you receive legal documents from another person in relation with property matters (like divorce papers), it can be frustrating if they take too long - especially since delays mean less time before things get complicated.
The law gives people certain protections against delay:

1) You have 28 days after receiving these notices ("papers") to file objections within local courts called "summary jurisdiction" offices. If there’s no objection filed by then, those orders become final as soon as signed at court on that day. 

If someone doesn’t sign them properly? That means their signature isn't really theirs because some other force made him write this document – like being threatened into signing under pressure! Then we call it “fraudulent” signatures; but even without fraud here
results.answer:
When you receive legal documents from another person in relation with property matters (like divorce papers), it can be frustrating if they take too long - especially since delays mean less time before things get complicated.
The law gives people certain protections against delay:

1) You have 28 days after receiving these notices ("papers") to file objections within local courts called "summary jurisdiction" offices. If there’s no objection filed by then, those orders become final as soon as signed at court on that day. 

If someone doesn’t sign them properly? That means their signature isn't really theirs because some other force made him write this document – like being threatened into signing under pressure!

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.
results.question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
Adoption is available only between close family members or relatives who live abroad.
In order to be eligible as an adoption agency you must have been registered with one of these agencies since 1984
The age limit on adopting children varies by country but generally ranges from two years old up until adulthood (usually around eighteen)
For more details please see our page about Adoption Eligibility Requirements

Please note that this answer was generated based solely upon publicly accessible government documents related directly to the topic at hand without any personal experience or opinions expressed hereinafter - it does not reflect my own beliefs nor experiences outside those contained within them
results.answer: Adoption is available only between close family members or relatives who live abroad.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.
results.question: How do penalty points work?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:
Penalty Points in Ireland operate on similar principles as those found elsewhere around Europe - they act like traffic fines that accumulate over time if you don't keep up with them by paying off any outstanding penalties or completing related court processes.
To get started understanding how this works:

1) If there is an offence (like parking illegally), it will result in one point being added onto your license plate number at random intervals throughout each year until paid-off

2) This means once 3 years have passed since adding these points then all three must be cleared before driving again
- Thereafter only two can remain after six months pass 

If not dealt-with within seven days from receipt date,
a fine equivalent to £70 would automatically apply instead  
And finally...
results.answer:

To get started understanding how this works:

1) If there is an offence (like parking illegally), it will result in one point being added onto your license plate number at random intervals throughout each year until paid-off

2) This means once 3 years have passed since adding these points then all three must be cleared before driving again
- Thereafter only two can remain after six months pass 

If not dealt-with within seven days from receipt date,
a fine equivalent to £70 would automatically apply instead  
And finally...

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.
results.question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Helpful Answer:
Yes, you do generally have rights regarding redundancy in many cases under employment law if employed by an employer with 12 or more employees (including self-employed). This is based on various laws such as Employment Rights Act 1996 which applies where there has been termination due to reasons like economic downturns affecting business operations.
However it can vary depending upon circumstances including whether this was voluntary decision made between yourself & company at outset before job offer etc., also any specific contract clauses may apply too! It’s important that when facing redundancies seek legal advice from qualified professional who understands local legislation well enough!
If unsure about specifics related directly here please check out resources provided locally via HR departments within workplaces themselves - they often know best what their own policies entail
results.answer:
Yes, you do generally have rights regarding redundancy in many cases under employment law if employed by an employer with 12 or more employees (including self-employed). This is based on various laws such as Employment Rights Act 1996 which applies where there has been termination due to reasons like economic downturns affecting business operations.
However it can vary depending upon circumstances including whether this was voluntary decision made between yourself & company at outset before job offer etc., also any specific contract clauses may apply too! It’s important that when facing redundancies seek legal advice from qualified professional who understands local legislation well enough!

results.ground_truth: You must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Birth certs for social welfare You are no longer required to provide copies of birth certificates for social welfare purposes if you were born in Ireland and your birth is in the Register of Births. The Department of Social Protection can access this information directly. You can get more information about getting a Birth, Marriage or Death certificate.

Question: How to apply for social welfare?

Helpful Answer:
Applying for Social Welfare in Ireland can be straightforward if you follow these steps:

1. **Determine Eligibility**: Check with Citizens Advice or local authorities about eligibility criteria based on income level.
2. **Fill Out Application Forms** (usually available online): You'll need forms that cover various aspects such as employment status, housing conditions, medical history etc., depending upon which benefit scheme is being applied under like Jobseeker’s Allowance/Universal Credit/Maternity Leave).
3. **Submit Applications Online/Centralized System:** Utilize either an electronic system provided by government bodies directly from home/on-the-go through their websites where applicants complete all required documents digitally before submitting them electronically via secure channels; this includes uploading supporting evidence along with personal details including

- **Determine Eligibility**: Check with Citizens Advice or local authorities about eligibility criteria based on income level.
- **Fill Out Application Forms** (usually available online): You'll need forms that cover various aspects such as employment status, housing conditions, medical history etc., depending upon which benefit scheme is being applied under like Jobseeker’s Allowance/Universal Credit/Maternity Leave).

You must also give your: Name Address Phone number Email address (if you have one)

Question: How can I comment on a planning application?

Helpful Answer:
To submit comments about an ongoing or proposed development in relation to land-use issues within Dublin City Council area (including Wicklow), you should contact them directly at their website [here](https://www.dublincitycouncil.ie/Planning-Applications). The process involves filling out this form with details such as who is making the request ("The applicant"), what they want done ("What action requested? "), where it will be located ("Where would these changes take place?" ), any concerns that need addressing "Any additional Comments?", why someone might object if approved by others ["Why do we think there may be objections"], how long has been going now / planned start date etc., then clicking'submit' when finished.
Once submitted through online portal provided here

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration

Question: What is the Citizens Information Service?

Helpful Answer:
The citizens' info (CIS) services in Ireland provide free advice on public sector matters including health care, education fees & loans etc.
To find out more about CIS please contact them directly by phone or email at 1890-675243
For general queries you can visit their website www.citizensinfo.ie

Is there anything else I should know? Yes, they also have an online help section which provides detailed guides covering all areas covered under CIS direct from home! They're open Monday - Friday between 9am – 5pm

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:
The Youth Enterprise Service is an initiative designed specifically with young people in mind as part of their transition from school or college into employment.
It provides support that includes financial assistance towards education expenses such as tuition fees; training opportunities like work experience placements;
accessible advice on how best to prepare oneself professionally by means including networking events,
and career development resources aimed at enhancing employability skills through structured courses;

YESS aims not only directly helping students who face difficulties securing jobs but also supports those seeking entry-level positions
by offering guidance tailored around specific needs based upon age groupings - e.g., 16-24 year-olds versus older workers transitioning careers – making sure they have all necessary tools needed before stepping out onto new paths within society post-schooling years

results.ground_truth: If you are a carer you may need to take breaks. Respite care is when you can take a break from caring, and the person you care for is looked after by someone else. It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Respite care can cover different lengths of time such as: A very short time, for example for an evening Or a much longer arrangement, for example for a holiday Respite care schemes are sometimes called 'Breakaway' or 'Friendship' schemes.
results.question: What is respite care?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is respite care?

Helpful Answer:
Respite Care refers to short-term assistance provided by caregivers or agencies who come into an individual’s home temporarily when they need help caring for their loved one with dementia (or other chronic conditions) because family members have work commitments that prevent them from providing regular caregiving support.
In simple terms it means someone comes in occasionally – perhaps once per week - during normal working hours so you can go out on errands without having to worry about how long those tasks will take. Respite services may be paid through insurance plans such as Medicare Part C/Medigap Plan D/Long Term Services & Supports coverage plan E/F/G/H/I/J/K/L under Section 1860d-24(d)(3), Medicaid Home Health Benefits Program Title
results.answer:
Respite Care refers to short-term assistance provided by caregivers or agencies who come into an individual’s home temporarily when they need help caring for their loved one with dementia (or other chronic conditions) because family members have work commitments that prevent them from providing regular caregiving support.
In simple terms it means someone comes in occasionally – perhaps once per week - during normal working hours so you can go out on errands without having to worry about how long those tasks will take.

results.ground_truth: If you have a medical card, you can get certain health services free of charge. Usually, your dependent spouse or partner and your children can also get the same range of health services for free. Your medical card is issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE).
results.question: What is a medical card?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is a medical card?

Helpful Answer:
A Medical Card in Northern Ireland was introduced on 1st July 2005 as part of an initiative by Sinn Fein (the political party) with support from some DUP politicians.
The new scheme replaced two previous schemes:

- The National Health Insurance Scheme - which had been around since before World War II
- A system that covered only hospital care

It covers all health services except dental treatment or prescriptions under certain circumstances such as mental illness where there has not yet been proper diagnosis etc...
For more details see https://www.dohni.gov.uk/medical-card/

Note this answer contains factual content about historical events but does provide limited context beyond what can be gleaned directly from its text alone; it also lacks any direct references outside itself
results.answer:
A Medical Card in Northern Ireland was introduced on 1st July 2005 as part of an initiative by Sinn Fein (the political party) with support from some DUP politicians.
The new scheme replaced two previous schemes:

- The National Health Insurance Scheme - which had been around since before World War II
- A system that covered only hospital care

It covers all health services except dental treatment or prescriptions under certain circumstances such as mental illness where there has not yet been proper diagnosis etc...
For more details see https://www.dohni.gov.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.
results.question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:
Pre-marriage contracts or "prenups" in Ireland do not have any specific statutory regulation but can be used as an agreement between spouses on matters such as property division upon divorce.
The validity depends solely on mutual consent; if both parties agree they may enter into them without fear that their marriage will become legally unstable due to financial issues post-divorce because there isn't legislation regulating these kinds of arrangements here at home yet either way you must still go through court proceedings when getting divorced which means it could end up being more expensive than just splitting things out yourself after separation anyway so I would recommend considering other options like living together openly before deciding whether this kind thing might work well enough instead

Please note, while my responses aim towards accuracy based on available data
results.answer: Pre-marriage contracts or "prenups" in Ireland do not have any specific statutory regulation but can be used as an agreement between spouses on matters such as property division upon divorce.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.
results.question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
The regulatory body that oversees air travel safety regulations is called Aer Lingus.
Aer Lingus was founded as an airline on 10 October 2004 by Air Eireann (the former state-owned national carrier), with its headquarters located at Dublin Airport Business Park adjacent to Terminal B thereon; it operates from various locations across Europe including Frankfurt, Madrid & Barcelona among others.
It provides services both domestically within the State itself and internationally through direct flights operated between major cities around Europe – London Heathrow being one such example - which connect passengers directly into destinations beyond our shores via European hubs like Paris or Amsterdam amongst other options available depending upon individual circumstances etc...
As well providing general passenger transportation facilities along side these more specialized routes we also offer
results.answer:
The regulatory body that oversees air travel safety regulations is called Aer Lingus.
Aer Lingus was founded as an airline on 10 October 2004 by Air Eireann (the former state-owned national carrier), with its headquarters located at Dublin Airport Business Park adjacent to Terminal B thereon; it operates from various locations across Europe including Frankfurt, Madrid & Barcelona among others.
It provides services both domestically within the State itself and internationally through direct flights operated between major cities around Europe – London Heathrow being one such example - which connect passengers directly into destinations beyond our shores via European hubs like Paris or Amsterdam amongst other options available depending upon individual circumstances etc...

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.
results.question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:
The cycle-to-work scheme allows people who work in public sector jobs (like teachers or civil servants) access discounted bikes through their employer if they meet certain criteria.
It works by giving employers money from central government that can be used towards buying new bicycles with specific features such as lights, helmets etc., which then have tax benefits when sold on at retail price.
Employers must pay 25% upfront but this gets refunded over time so it doesn't cost them anything until after one year has passed since receiving funding - though there will still need to be ongoing maintenance costs covered elsewhere e.g insurance
There was an increase last April allowing more types of employment including private businesses like cafes & restaurants where previously only those directly employed could take part

This means staff

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:
The Dublin Light Rail (Luas) operates from 05:30 until midnight daily in peak times on weekdays during rush hour periods only - typically between about 8am-9pm Monday through Friday.
During offpeak or non-rush-hour timeframes it runs approximately every ten minutes along most routes but this may vary depending upon traffic conditions at any given moment as well as other factors such as maintenance work being carried out by train operators. 

Please note that there can be delays due to unforeseen circumstances including weather changes affecting travel patterns across our network; please check with us if you need further details regarding specific services when traveling within Greater Dublin Area today! The latest schedule will always provide an up-to-date picture so keep checking back frequently!
